p: The antihyperglycemic activity of T. serrulatus aqueous extract and essential oil was performed according to the method described by Kabbaoui et al. (2016). The mice were equally divided and randomly assigned into nine groups of six mice ( n = 6) each: Group 1: healthy mice received the vehicle (2% tween 80, 10 ml/kg) and served as normal control group. Group 2: diabetic mice received a daily oral dose of 2% tween 80 (10 ml/kg), served as diabetic control group. Groups 3, 4, and 5: diabetic mice received a daily oral dose of 150, 300, and 600 mg/kg aqueous extract, respectively. Groups 6, 7, and 8: diabetic mice received a daily oral dose of 150, 300, and 600 mg/kg of the essential oil respectively. Group 9: diabetic mice received a daily oral dose of 10 mg/kg of the standard drug glibenclamide and served as a positive control group. The test samples, standard drug, and vehicle were started 3 days after induction of diabetes and administered orally on a once daily basis for 21 days using oral gavage.
